1219 # --- Declaration --- 

1220 # Set evaluation methods 

1221 def SetEvalMethod(self, coeffs=None, method=None, args=None, *a, **kw): 

1222 r"""Set evaluation method for a one or more coefficients 

1223 

1224 :Call: 

1225 >>> DBc.SetEvalMethod(coeff, method=None, args=None, **kw) 

1226 >>> DBc.SetEvalMethod(coeffs, method=None, args=None, **kw) 

1227 :Inputs: 

1228 *DBc*: :class:`DBCoeff` 

1229 Coefficient database interface 

1230 *coeffs*: :class:`list` (:class:`str` | :class:`unicode`) 

1231 List of coefficients to declare 

1232 *coeff*: :class:`str` | :class:`unicode` 

1233 Name of coefficient to evaluate 

1234 *method*: ``"nearest"`` | ``"linear"`` | ``"rbf"`` | :class:`str` 

1235 Interpolation/evaluation method 

1236 *args*: :class:`list` (:class:`str`) 

1237 List of input arguments 

1238 *aliases*: {``{}``} | :class:`dict` (:class:`str`) 

1239 Dictionary of alternate variable names during evaluation; if 

1240 *aliases[k1]* is *k2*, that means *k1* is an alternate name for 

1241 *k2*, and *k2* is in *args* 

1242 *eval_kwargs*: {``{}``} | :class:`dict` 

1243 Keyword arguments passed to functions 

1244 *I*: {``None``} | :class:`np.ndarray` 

1245 Indices of cases to include in RBF (default is all) 

1246 *function*: {``"cubic"``} | :class:`str` 

1247 Radial basis function type 

1248 *smooth*: {``0.0``} | :class:`float` >= 0 

1249 Smoothing factor, ``0.0`` for exact interpolation 

1250 :Versions: 

1251 * 2019-01-07 ``@ddalle``: First version 

1252 """ 

1253 # Get coefficients type 

1254 t = coeffs.__class__.__name__ 

1255 # Check for list 

1256 if t not in ["list", "ndarray"]: 

1257 # Singleton list 

1258 coeffs = [coeffs] 

1259 # Loop through coefficients 

1260 for coeff in coeffs: 

1261 self._set_method1(coeff, method, args, *a, **kw) 

1262 

1263 # Save a method for one coefficient 

1264 def _set_method1(self, coeff=None, method=None, args=None, *a, **kw): 

1265 """Set evaluation method for a single coefficient 

1266 

1267 :Call: 

1268 >>> DBc._set_method1(coeff=None, method=None, args=None, **kw) 

1269 :Inputs: 

1270 *DBc*: :class:`DBCoeff` 

1271 Coefficient database interface 

1272 *coeff*: :class:`str` | :class:`unicode` 

1273 Name of coefficient to evaluate 

1274 *method*: ``"nearest"`` | ``"linear"`` | ``"rbf"`` | :class:`str` 

1275 Interpolation/evaluation method 

1276 *args*: :class:`list` (:class:`str`) 

1277 List of input arguments 

1278 *aliases*: {``{}``} | :class:`dict` (:class:`str`) 

1279 Dictionary of alternate variable names during evaluation; if 

1280 *aliases[k1]* is *k2*, that means *k1* is an alternate name for 

1281 *k2*, and *k2* is in *args* 

1282 *eval_kwargs*: {``{}``} | :class:`dict` 

1283 Keyword arguments passed to functions 

1284 *I*: {``None``} | :class:`np.ndarray` 

1285 Indices of cases to include in RBF (default is all) 

1286 *function*: {``"cubic"``} | :class:`str` 

1287 Radial basis function type 

1288 *smooth*: {``0.0``} | :class:`float` >= 0 

1289 Smoothing factor, ``0.0`` for exact interpolation 

1290 :Versions: 

1291 * 2019-01-07 ``@ddalle``: First version 

1292 """ 

1293 # --- Metadata checks --- 

1294 # Ensure metadata is present 

1295 try: 

1296 # Access dictionary of evaluation method 

1297 self.eval_method 

1298 except AttributeError: 

1299 # Create it 

1300 self.eval_method = {} 

1301 # Argument lists 

1302 try: 

1303 # Access dictionary of argument lists 

1304 self.eval_args 

1305 except AttributeError: 

1306 # Create it 

1307 self.eval_args = {} 

1308 # Argument aliases 

1309 try: 

1310 # Access dictionary of argument alias names 

1311 self.eval_arg_aliases 

1312 except AttributeError: 

1313 # Create it 

1314 self.eval_arg_aliases = {} 

1315 # Evaluation keyword arguments 

1316 try: 

1317 # Access dictionary of keywords to evaluators 

1318 self.eval_kwargs 

1319 except AttributeError: 

1320 # Create it 

1321 self.eval_kwargs = {} 

1322 # --- Input checks --- 

1323 # Check inputs 

1324 if coeff is None: 

1325 # Set the default 

1326 coeff = "_" 

1327 # Check for valid argument list 

1328 if args is None: 

1329 raise ValueError("Argument list (keyword 'args') is required") 

1330 # Check for method 

1331 if method is None: 

1332 raise ValueError("Eval method (keyword 'method') is required") 

1333 # Get alias option 

1334 arg_aliases = kw.get("aliases", {}) 

1335 # Check for ``None`` 

1336 if (not arg_aliases): 

1337 # Empty option is empty dictionary 

1338 arg_aliases = {} 

1339 # Save aliases 

1340 self.eval_arg_aliases[coeff] = arg_aliases 

1341 # Get alias option 

1342 eval_kwargs = kw.get("eval_kwargs", {}) 

1343 # Check for ``None`` 

1344 if (not eval_kwargs): 

1345 # Empty option is empty dictionary 

1346 eval_kwargs = {} 

1347 # Save keywords (new copy) 

1348 self.eval_kwargs[coeff] = dict(eval_kwargs) 

1349 # --- Method switch --- 

1350 # Check for identifiable method 

1351 if method in ["nearest"]: 

1352 # Nearest-neighbor lookup 

1353 self.eval_method[coeff] = "nearest" 

1354 elif method in ["linear", "multilinear"]: 

1355 # Linear/multilinear interpolation 

1356 self.eval_method[coeff] = "multilinear" 

1357 elif method in ["linear-schedule", "multilinear-schedule"]: 

1358 # (N-1)D linear interp in last keys, 1D in first key 

1359 self.eval_method[coeff] = "multilinear-schedule" 

1360 elif method in ["rbf", "rbg-global", "rbf0"]: 

1361 # Create global RBF 

1362 self.CreateGlobalRBFs([coeff], args, **kw) 

1363 # Metadata 

1364 self.eval_method[coeff] = "rbf" 

1365 elif method in ["lin-rbf", "rbf-linear", "linear-rbf"]: 

1366 # Create RBFs on slices 

1367 self.CreateSliceRBFs([coeff], args, **kw) 

1368 # Metadata 

1369 self.eval_method[coeff] = "rbf-linear" 

1370 elif method in ["map-rbf", "rbf-schedule", "rbf-map", "rbf1"]: 

1371 # Create RBFs on slices but scheduled 

1372 self.CreateSliceRBFs([coeff], args, **kw) 

1373 # Metadata 

1374 self.eval_method[coeff] = "rbf-map" 

1375 elif method in ["function", "fn", "func"]: 

1376 # Create eval_func dictionary 

1377 try: 

1378 self.eval_func 

1379 except AttributeError: 

1380 self.eval_func = {} 

1381 # Create eval_func dictionary 

1382 try: 

1383 self.eval_func_self 

1384 except AttributeError: 

1385 self.eval_func_self = {} 

1386 # Get the function 

1387 if len(a) > 0: 

1388 # Function given as arg 

1389 fn = a[0] 

1390 else: 

1391 # Function better be a keyword because there are no args 

1392 fn = None 

1393 

1394 # Save the function 

1395 self.eval_func[coeff] = kw.get("function", kw.get("func", fn)) 

1396 self.eval_func_self[coeff] = kw.get("self", True) 

1397 

1398 # Dedicated function 

1399 self.eval_method[coeff] = "function" 

1400 else: 

1401 raise ValueError( 

1402 "Did not recognize evaluation type '%s'" % method) 

1403 # Argument list is the same for all methods 

1404 self.eval_args[coeff] = args 

1405 

1406 # --- Schedule Tools --- 

1407 # Return break points for schedule 

1408 def get_schedule(self, args, x, extrap=True): 

1409 """Get lookup points for interpolation scheduled by master key 

1410 

1411 This is a utility that is used for situations where the break 

1412 points of some keys may vary as a schedule of another one. 

1413 For example if the maximum angle of attack in the database is 

1414 different at each Mach number. This utility provides the 

1415 appropriate point at which to interpolate the remaining keys 

1416 at the value of the first key both above and below the input 

1417 value. The first argument, ``args[0]``, is the master key 

1418 that controls the schedule. 

1419 

1420 :Call: 

1421 >>> i0, i1, f, x0, x1 = DBc.get_schedule(args, x, **kw) 

1422 :Inputs: 

1423 *DBc*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

1424 Coefficient database interface 

1425 *args*: :class:`list` (:class:`str`) 

1426 List of input argument names (*args[0]* is master key) 

1427 *x*: :class:`list` | :class:`tuple` | :class:`np.ndarray` 

1428 Vector of values for each argument in *args* 

1429 *extrap*: {``True``} | ``False`` 

1430 If ``False``, raise error when lookup value is outside 

1431 break point range for any key at any slice 

1432 :Outputs: 

1433 *i0*: ``None`` | :class:`int` 

1434 Lower bound index, if ``None``, extrapolation below 

1435 *i1*: ``None`` | :class:`int` 

1436 Upper bound index, if ``None``, extrapolation above 

1437 *f*: 0 <= :class:`float` <= 1 

1438 Lookup fraction, ``1.0`` if *v* is at upper bound 

1439 *x0*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`float`] 

1440 Evaluation values for ``args[1:]`` at *i0* 

1441 *x1*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`float`] 

1442 Evaluation values for ``args[1:]`` at *i1* 

1443 :Versions: 

1444 * 2019-04-19 ``@ddalle``: First version 

1445 * 2019-07-26 ``@ddalle``: Vectorized 

1446 """ 

1447 # Number of args 

1448 narg = len(args) 

1449 # Error check 

1450 if narg < 2: 

1451 raise ValueError("At least two args required for scheduled lookup") 

1452 # Flag for array or scalar 

1453 qvec = False 

1454 # Number of points in arrays (if any) 

1455 n = None 

1456 # Loop through args 

1457 for i, k in enumerate(args): 

1458 # Get value 

1459 V = x[i] 

1460 # Check type 

1461 if typeutils.isarray(V): 

1462 # Turn on array flag 

1463 qvec = True 

1464 # Get size 

1465 nk = len(V) 

1466 # Check consistency 

1467 if n is None: 

1468 # New size 

1469 n = nk 

1470 elif nk != n: 

1471 # Inconsistent size 

1472 raise ValueError( 

1473 "Eval arg '%s' has size %i, expected %i" % (k, nk, n)) 

1474 elif not isinstance(V, (float, int, np.ndarray)): 

1475 # Improper type 

1476 raise TypeError( 

1477 "Eval arg '%s' has type '%s'" % (k, V.__class__.__name__)) 

1478 # Check for arrays 

1479 if not qvec: 

1480 # Call scalar version 

1481 return self._get_schedule(args, x, extrap=extrap) 

1482 # Initialize tuple of fixed-size lookup points 

1483 X = tuple() 

1484 # Loop through args again 

1485 for i, k in enumerate(args): 

1486 # Get value 

1487 V = x[i] 

1488 # Check type 

1489 if isinstance(V, (float, int)): 

1490 # Create constant-value array 

1491 X += (V * np.ones(n),) 

1492 else: 

1493 # Copy array 

1494 X += (V,) 

1495 # Otherwise initialize arrays 

1496 I0 = np.zeros(n, dtype="int") 

1497 I1 = np.zeros(n, dtype="int") 

1498 F = np.zeros(n) 

1499 # Initialize tuples of modified lookup points 

1500 X0 = tuple([np.zeros(n) for i in range(narg-1)]) 

1501 X1 = tuple([np.zeros(n) for i in range(narg-1)]) 

1502 # Loop through points 

1503 for j in range(n): 

1504 # Get lookup points 

1505 xj = tuple([X[i][j] for i in range(narg)]) 

1506 # Evaluations 

1507 i0, i1, f, x0, x1 = self._get_schedule( 

1508 list(args), xj, extrap=extrap) 

1509 # Save indices 

1510 I0[j] = i0 

1511 I1[j] = i1 

1512 # Save lookup fraction 

1513 F[j] = f 

1514 # Save modified lookup points 

1515 for i in range(narg-1): 

1516 X0[i][j] = x0[i] 

1517 X1[i][j] = x1[i] 

1518 # Output 

1519 return I0, I1, F, X0, X1 

1520 

1521 # Return break points for schedule 

1522 def _get_schedule(self, args, x, extrap=True): 

1523 """Get lookup points for interpolation scheduled by master key 

1524 

1525 This is a utility that is used for situations where the break 

1526 points of some keys may vary as a schedule of another one. 

1527 For example if the maximum angle of attack in the database is 

1528 different at each Mach number. This utility provides the 

1529 appropriate point at which to interpolate the remaining keys 

1530 at the value of the first key both above and below the input 

1531 value. The first argument, ``args[0]``, is the master key 

1532 that controls the schedule. 

1533 

1534 :Call: 

1535 >>> i0, i1, f, x0, x1 = DBc.get_schedule(args, x, **kw) 

1536 :Inputs: 

1537 *DBc*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

1538 Coefficient database interface 

1539 *args*: :class:`list` (:class:`str`) 

1540 List of input argument names (*args[0]* is master key) 

1541 *x*: :class:`list` | :class:`tuple` | :class:`np.ndarray` 

1542 Vector of values for each argument in *args* 

1543 *extrap*: {``True``} | ``False`` 

1544 If ``False``, raise error when lookup value is outside 

1545 break point range for any key at any slice 

1546 :Outputs: 

1547 *i0*: ``None`` | :class:`int` 

1548 Lower bound index, if ``None``, extrapolation below 

1549 *i1*: ``None`` | :class:`int` 

1550 Upper bound index, if ``None``, extrapolation above 

1551 *f*: 0 <= :class:`float` <= 1 

1552 Lookup fraction, ``1.0`` if *v* is at upper bound 

1553 *x0*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`float`] 

1554 Evaluation values for ``args[1:]`` at *i0* 

1555 *x1*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`float`] 

1556 Evaluation values for ``args[1:]`` at *i1* 

1557 :Versions: 

1558 * 2019-04-19 ``@ddalle``: First version 

1559 """ 

1560 # Error check 

1561 if len(args) < 2: 

1562 raise ValueError("At least two args required for scheduled lookup") 

1563 # Slice/scheduling key 

1564 skey = args.pop(0) 

1565 # Lookup value for first variable 

1566 i0, i1, f = self.get_bkpt_index(skey, x[0]) 

1567 # Number of additional args 

1568 narg = len(args) 

1569 # Initialize lookup points at slice *i0* and slice *i1* 

1570 x0 = np.zeros(narg) 

1571 x1 = np.zeros(narg) 

1572 # Loop through arguments 

1573 for j, k in enumerate(args): 

1574 # Get min and max values 

1575 try: 

1576 # Try the case of varying break points indexed to *skey* 

1577 xmin0 = self.get_bkpt(k, i0, 0) 

1578 xmin1 = self.get_bkpt(k, i1, 0) 

1579 xmax0 = self.get_bkpt(k, i0, -1) 

1580 xmax1 = self.get_bkpt(k, i1, -1) 

1581 except TypeError: 

1582 # Fixed break points (apparently) 

1583 xmin0 = self.get_bkpt(k, 0) 

1584 xmin1 = self.get_bkpt(k, 0) 

1585 xmax0 = self.get_bkpt(k, -1) 

1586 xmax1 = self.get_bkpt(k, -1) 

1587 # Interpolate to current *skey* value 

1588 xmin = (1-f)*xmin0 + f*xmin1 

1589 xmax = (1-f)*xmax0 + f*xmax1 

1590 # Get the progress fraction at current inter-slice *skey* value 

1591 fj = (x[j+1] - xmin) / (xmax-xmin) 

1592 # Check for extrapolation 

1593 if not extrap and ((fj < -1e-3) or (fj - 1 > 1e-3)): 

1594 # Raise extrapolation error 

1595 raise ValueError( 

1596 ("Lookup value %.4e is outside " % x[j+1]) + 

1597 ("scheduled bounds [%.4e, %.4e]" % (xmin, xmax))) 

1598 # Get lookup points at slices *i0* and *i1* using this prog frac 

1599 x0[j] = (1-fj)*xmin0 + fj*xmax0 

1600 x1[j] = (1-fj)*xmin1 + fj*xmax1 

1601 # Output 

1602 return i0, i1, f, x0, x1 

1603 

1604 # --- Breakpoints --- 

1605 # Function to get interpolation weights for uq 

1606 def get_bkpt_index(self, k, v): 

1607 """Get interpolation weights for 1D linear interpolation 

1608 

1609 :Call: 

1610 >>> i0, i1, f = DBc.get_bkpt_index(k, v) 

1611 :Inputs: 

1612 *DBc*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

1613 Coefficient database interface 

1614 *k*: :class:`str` 

1615 Name of trajectory key in *FM.bkpts* for lookup 

1616 *v*: :class:`float` 

1617 Value at which to lookup 

1618 :Outputs: 

1619 *i0*: ``None`` | :class:`int` 

1620 Lower bound index, if ``None``, extrapolation below 

1621 *i1*: ``None`` | :class:`int` 

1622 Upper bound index, if ``None``, extrapolation above 

1623 *f*: 0 <= :class:`float` <= 1 

1624 Lookup fraction, ``1.0`` if *v* is equal to upper bound 

1625 :Versions: 

1626 * 2018-12-30 ``@ddalle``: First version 

1627 """ 

1628 # Extract values 

1629 try: 

1630 # Naive extractions 

1631 V = np.asarray(self.bkpts[k]) 

1632 except AttributeError: 

1633 # No break points 

1634 raise AttributeError("No break point dictionary present") 

1635 except KeyError: 

1636 # Missing key 

1637 raise KeyError( 

1638 "Lookup key '%s' is not present in break point dict" % k) 

1639 # Output 

1640 return self._bkpt_index(V, v) 

1641 

1642 # Function to get interpolation weights for uq 

1643 def get_bkpt_index_schedule(self, k, v, j): 

1644 """Get weights 1D interpolation of *k* at a slice of master key 

1645 

1646 :Call: 

1647 >>> i0, i1, f = DBc.get_bkpt_index_schedule(k, v, j) 

1648 :Inputs: 

1649 *DBc*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

1650 Coefficient database interface 

1651 *k*: :class:`str` 

1652 Name of trajectory key in *FM.bkpts* for lookup 

1653 *v*: :class:`float` 

1654 Value at which to lookup 

1655 *j*: :class:`int` 

1656 Index of master "slice" key, if *k* has scheduled 

1657 break points 

1658 :Outputs: 

1659 *i0*: ``None`` | :class:`int` 

1660 Lower bound index, if ``None``, extrapolation below 

1661 *i1*: ``None`` | :class:`int` 

1662 Upper bound index, if ``None``, extrapolation above 

1663 *f*: 0 <= :class:`float` <= 1 

1664 Lookup fraction, ``1.0`` if *v* is equal to upper bound 

1665 :Versions: 

1666 * 2018-04-19 ``@ddalle``: First version 

1667 """ 

1668 # Get potential values 

1669 V = self._scheduled_bkpts(k, j) 

1670 # Lookup within this vector 

1671 return self._bkpt(V, v) 

1672 

1673 # Get break point from vector 

1674 def _bkpt_index(self, V, v): 

1675 """Get interpolation weights for 1D interpolation 

1676 

1677 :Call: 

1678 >>> i0, i1, f = DBc._bkpt_index(V, v) 

1679 :Inputs: 

1680 *DBc*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

1681 Coefficient database interface 

1682 *V*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`float`] 

1683 1D array of data values 

1684 *v*: :class:`float` 

1685 Value at which to lookup 

1686 :Outputs: 

1687 *i0*: ``None`` | :class:`int` 

1688 Lower bound index, if ``None``, extrapolation below 

1689 *i1*: ``None`` | :class:`int` 

1690 Upper bound index, if ``None``, extrapolation above 

1691 *f*: 0 <= :class:`float` <= 1 

1692 Lookup fraction, ``1.0`` if *v* is equal to upper bound 

1693 :Versions: 

1694 * 2018-12-30 ``@ddalle``: First version 

1695 """ 

1696 # Get length 

1697 n = V.size 

1698 # Get min/max 

1699 vmin = np.min(V) 

1700 vmax = np.max(V) 

1701 # Check for extrapolation cases 

1702 if v < vmin - 1e-8*(vmax-vmin): 

1703 # Extrapolation left 

1704 return None, 0, 1.0 

1705 elif v > vmax + 1e-8*(vmax-vmin): 

1706 # Extrapolation right 

1707 return n-1, None, 1.0 

1708 # Otherwise, count up values below 

1709 i0 = np.sum(V[:-1] <= v) - 1 

1710 i1 = i0 + 1 

1711 # Progress fraction 

1712 f = (v - V[i0]) / (V[i1] - V[i0]) 

1713 # Output 

1714 return i0, i1, f 

1715 

1716 # Get a break point, with error checking 

1717 def get_bkpt(self, k, *I): 

1718 """Extract a breakpoint by index, with error checking 

1719 

1720 :Call: 

1721 >>> v = DBc.get_bkpt(k, *I) 

1722 >>> v = DBc.get_bkpt(k) 

1723 >>> v = DBc.get_bkpt(k, i) 

1724 >>> v = DBc.get_bkpt(k, i, j) 

1725 >>> v = DBc.get_bkpt(k, i, j, ...) 

1726 :Inputs: 

1727 *DBc*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

1728 Coefficient database interface 

1729 *coeff*: :class:`str` 

1730 Name of coefficient to evaluate 

1731 *I*: :class:`tuple` 

1732 Tuple of lookup indices 

1733 *i*: :class:`int` 

1734 (Optional) first RBF list index 

1735 *j*: :class:`int` 

1736 (Optional) second RBF list index 

1737 :Outputs: 

1738 *v*: :class:`float` | :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`float`] 

1739 Break point or array of break points 

1740 :Versions: 

1741 * 2018-12-31 ``@ddalle``: First version 

1742 """ 

1743 # Get the radial basis function 

1744 try: 

1745 v = self.bkpts[k] 

1746 except AttributeError: 

1747 # No radial basis functions at all 

1748 raise AttributeError("No break points found") 

1749 except KeyError: 

1750 # No RBF for this coefficient 

1751 raise KeyError("No break points for key '%s'" % k) 

1752 # Number of indices given 

1753 nd = len(I) 

1754 # Loop through indices 

1755 for n, i in enumerate(I): 

1756 # Try to extract 

1757 try: 

1758 # Get the *ith* list entry 

1759 v = v[i] 

1760 except (IndexError, TypeError): 

1761 # Reached scalar too soon 

1762 raise TypeError( 

1763 ("Breakpoints for '%s':\n" % k) + 

1764 ("Expecting %i-dimensional " % nd) + 

1765 ("array but found %i-dim" % n)) 

1766 # Output 

1767 return v 

1768 

1769 # Get all break points 

1770 def _scheduled_bkpts(self, k, j): 

1771 """Get list of break points for key *k* at schedule *j* 

1772 

1773 :Call: 

1774 *DBc*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

1775 Coefficient database interface 

1776 *k*: :class:`str` 

1777 Name of trajectory key in *FM.bkpts* for lookup 

1778 *j*: :class:`int` 

1779 Index of master "slice" key, if *k* has scheduled 

1780 break points 

1781 :Outputs: 

1782 *i0*: ``None`` | :class:`int` 

1783 Lower bound index, if ``None``, extrapolation below 

1784 *i1*: ``None`` | :class:`int` 

1785 Upper bound index, if ``None``, extrapolation above 

1786 *f*: 0 <= :class:`float` <= 1 

1787 Lookup fraction, ``1.0`` if *v* is equal to upper bound 

1788 :Versions: 

1789 * 2018-12-30 ``@ddalle``: First version 

1790 """ 

1791 # Get the radial basis function 

1792 try: 

1793 V = self.bkpts[k] 

1794 except AttributeError: 

1795 # No radial basis functions at all 

1796 raise AttributeError("No break points found") 

1797 except KeyError: 

1798 # No RBF for this coefficient 

1799 raise KeyError("No break points for key '%s'" % str(k)) 

1800 # Get length 

1801 n = len(V) 

1802 # Size check 

1803 if n == 0: 

1804 raise ValueError("Found zero break points for key '%s'" % k) 

1805 # Check first key for array 

1806 if isinstance(V[0], (np.ndarray, list)): 

1807 # Get break points for this slice 

1808 V = V[j] 

1809 # Reset size 

1810 n = V.size 

1811 # Recheck size 

1812 if n == 0: 

1813 raise ValueError("Found zero break points for key '%s'" % k) 

1814 # Output 

1815 return V 

1816 

1817 # --- Linear --- 

1818 # Multilinear lookup 

1819 def eval_multilinear(self, coeff, args, x, **kw): 

1820 """Perform linear interpolation in as many dimensions as necessary 

1821 

1822 This assumes the database is ordered with the first entry of *args* 

1823 varying the most slowly and that the data is perfectly regular. 

1824 

1825 :Call: 

1826 >>> y = DBc.eval_multilinear(coeff, args, x) 

1827 :Inputs: 

1828 *DBc*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

1829 Coefficient database interface 

1830 *coeff*: :class:`str` 

1831 Name of coefficient to evaluate 

1832 *args*: :class:`list` | :class:`tuple` 

1833 List of lookup key names 

1834 *x*: :class:`list` | :class:`tuple` | :class:`np.ndarray` 

1835 Vector of values for each argument in *args* 

1836 *bkpt*: ``True`` | {``False``} 

1837 Whether or not to interpolate break points instead of data 

1838 :Outputs: 

1839 *y*: ``None`` | :class:`float` | ``DBc[coeff].__class__`` 

1840 Interpolated value from ``DBc[coeff]`` 

1841 :Versions: 

1842 * 2018-12-30 ``@ddalle``: First version 

1843 """ 

1844 # Call root method without two of the options 

1845 return self._eval_multilinear(coeff, args, x, **kw) 

1846 

1847 # Evaluate multilinear interpolation with caveats 

1848 def _eval_multilinear(self, coeff, args, x, I=None, j=None, **kw): 

1849 """Perform linear interpolation in as many dimensions as necessary 

1850 

1851 This assumes the database is ordered with the first entry of *args* 

1852 varying the most slowly and that the data is perfectly regular. 

1853 

1854 :Call: 

1855 >>> y = DBc._eval_multilinear(coeff, args, x, I=None, j=None) 

1856 :Inputs: 

1857 *DBc*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

1858 Coefficient database interface 

1859 *coeff*: :class:`str` 

1860 Name of coefficient to evaluate 

1861 *args*: :class:`list` | :class:`tuple` 

1862 List of lookup key names 

1863 *x*: :class:`list` | :class:`tuple` | :class:`np.ndarray` 

1864 Vector of values for each argument in *args* 

1865 *I*: {``None``} | :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`int`] 

1866 Optional subset of database on which to perform 

1867 interpolation 

1868 *j*: {``None``} | :class:`int` 

1869 Slice index, used by :func:`eval_multilinear_schedule` 

1870 *bkpt*: ``True`` | {``False``} 

1871 Whether or not to interpolate break points instead of data 

1872 :Outputs: 

1873 *y*: ``None`` | :class:`float` | ``DBc[coeff].__class__`` 

1874 Interpolated value from ``DBc[coeff]`` 

1875 :Versions: 

1876 * 2018-12-30 ``@ddalle``: First version 

1877 * 2019-04-19 ``@ddalle``: Moved from :func:`eval_multilnear` 

1878 """ 

1879 # Check for break-point evaluation flag 

1880 bkpt = kw.get("bkpt", kw.get("breakpoint", False)) 

1881 # Possible values 

1882 try: 

1883 # Extract coefficient 

1884 if bkpt: 

1885 # Lookup from breakpoints 

1886 V = self.bkpts[coeff] 

1887 else: 

1888 # Lookup from main data 

1889 V = self[coeff] 

1890 except KeyError: 

1891 # Missing key 

1892 raise KeyError("Coefficient '%s' is not present" % coeff) 

1893 # Subset if appropriate 

1894 if I is not None: 

1895 # Attempt to subset 

1896 try: 

1897 # Select some indices 

1898 V = V[I] 

1899 except Exception: 

1900 # Informative error 

1901 raise ValueError( 

1902 "Failed to subset coeff '%s' using class '%s'" 

1903 % (coeff, I.__class__.__name__)) 

1904 # Number of keys 

1905 nk = len(args) 

1906 # Count 

1907 n = len(V) 

1908 # Get break points for this schedule 

1909 bkpts = {} 

1910 for k in args: 

1911 bkpts[k] = self._scheduled_bkpts(k, j) 

1912 # Lengths for each variable 

1913 N = [len(bkpts[k]) for k in args] 

1914 # Check consistency 

1915 if np.prod(N) != n: 

1916 raise ValueError( 

1917 ("Coefficient '%s' has size %i, " % (coeff, n)), 

1918 ("but total size of args %s is %i." % (args, np.prod(N)))) 

1919 # Initialize list of indices for each key 

1920 I0 = [] 

1921 I1 = [] 

1922 F1 = [] 

1923 # Get lookup indices for each argument 

1924 for i, k in enumerate(args): 

1925 # Lookup value 

1926 xi = x[i] 

1927 # Values 

1928 Vk = bkpts[k] 

1929 # Get indices 

1930 i0, i1, f = self._bkpt_index(Vk, xi) 

1931 # Check for problems 

1932 if i0 is None: 

1933 # Below 

1934 raise ValueError( 

1935 ("Value %s=%.4e " % (k, xi)) + 

1936 ("below lower bound (%.4e)" % Vk[0])) 

1937 elif i1 is None: 

1938 raise ValueError( 

1939 ("Value %s=%.4e " % (k, xi)) + 

1940 ("above upper bound (%.4e)" % Vk[-1])) 

1941 # Save values 

1942 I0.append(i0) 

1943 I1.append(i1) 

1944 F1.append(f) 

1945 # Index of the lowest corner 

1946 j0 = 0 

1947 # Loop through the keys 

1948 for i in range(nk): 

1949 # Get value 

1950 i0 = I0[i] 

1951 # Overall ; multiply index by size of remaining block 

1952 j0 += i0 * int(np.prod(N[i+1:])) 

1953 # Initialize overall indices and weights 

1954 J = j0 * np.ones(2**nk, dtype="int") 

1955 F = np.ones(2**nk) 

1956 # Counter from 0 to 2^nk-1 

1957 E = np.arange(2**nk) 

1958 # Loop through keys again 

1959 for i in range(nk): 

1960 # Exponent of two to use for this key 

1961 e = nk - i 

1962 # Up or down for each of the 2^nk individual lookup points 

1963 jupdown = E % 2**e // 2**(e-1) 

1964 # Size of remaining block 

1965 subblock = int(np.prod(N[i+1:])) 

1966 # Increment overall indices 

1967 J += jupdown*subblock 

1968 # Progress fraction for this variable 

1969 fi = F1[i] 

1970 # Convert up/down to either fi or 1-fi 

1971 Fi = (1-fi)*(1-jupdown) + jupdown*fi 

1972 # Apply weights 

1973 F *= Fi 

1974 # Perform interpolation 

1975 return np.sum(F*V[J]) 

1976 

1977 # --- Multilinear-schedule --- 

1978 # Multilinear lookup at each value of arg 

1979 def eval_multilinear_schedule(self, coeff, args, x, **kw): 

1980 """Perform linear interpolation in as many dimensions as necessary 

1981 

1982 This assumes the database is ordered with the first entry of *args* 

1983 varying the most slowly and that the data is perfectly regular. 

1984 

1985 :Call: 

1986 >>> y = DBc.eval_multilinear(coeff, args, x) 

1987 :Inputs: 

1988 *DBc*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

1989 Coefficient database interface 

1990 *coeff*: :class:`str` 

1991 Name of coefficient to evaluate 

1992 *args*: :class:`list` | :class:`tuple` 

1993 List of lookup key names 

1994 *x*: :class:`list` | :class:`tuple` | :class:`np.ndarray` 

1995 Vector of values for each argument in *args* 

1996 *tol*: {``1e-6``} | :class:`float` >= 0 

1997 Tolerance for matching slice key 

1998 :Outputs: 

1999 *y*: ``None`` | :class:`float` | ``DBc[coeff].__class__`` 

2000 Interpolated value from ``DBc[coeff]`` 

2001 :Versions: 

2002 * 2019-04-19 ``@ddalle``: First version 

2003 """ 

2004 # Slice tolerance 

2005 tol = kw.get("tol", 1e-6) 

2006 # Name of master (slice) key 

2007 skey = args[0] 

2008 # Get lookup points at both sides of scheduling key 

2009 i0, i1, f, x0, x1 = self.get_schedule(args, x, extrap=False) 

2010 # Get the values for the slice key 

2011 x00 = self.get_bkpt(skey, i0) 

2012 x01 = self.get_bkpt(skey, i1) 

2013 # Find indices of the two slices 

2014 I0 = np.where(np.abs(self[skey] - x00) <= tol)[0] 

2015 I1 = np.where(np.abs(self[skey] - x01) <= tol)[0] 

2016 # Perform interpolations 

2017 y0 = self._eval_multilinear(coeff, args, x0, I=I0, j=i0) 

2018 y1 = self._eval_multilinear(coeff, args, x1, I=I1, j=i1) 

2019 # Linear interpolation in the schedule key 

2020 return (1-f)*y0 + f*y1 

2021 

2022 # --- Radial Basis Functions --- 

2023 # Get an RBF 

2024 def get_rbf(self, coeff, *I): 

2025 """Extract a radial basis function, with error checking 

2026 

2027 :Call: 

2028 >>> f = DBc.get_rbf(coeff, *I) 

2029 >>> f = DBc.get_rbf(coeff) 

2030 >>> f = DBc.get_rbf(coeff, i) 

2031 >>> f = DBc.get_rbf(coeff, i, j) 

2032 >>> f = DBc.get_rbf(coeff, i, j, ...) 

2033 :Inputs: 

2034 *DBc*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

2035 Coefficient database interface 

2036 *coeff*: :class:`str` 

2037 Name of coefficient to evaluate 

2038 *I*: :class:`tuple` 

2039 Tuple of lookup indices 

2040 *i*: :class:`int` 

2041 (Optional) first RBF list index 

2042 *j*: :class:`int` 

2043 (Optional) second RBF list index 

2044 :Outputs: 

2045 *f*: :class:`scipy.interpolate.rbf.Rbf` 

2046 Callable radial basis function 

2047 :Versions: 

2048 * 2018-12-31 ``@ddalle``: First version 

2049 """ 

2050 # Get the radial basis function 

2051 try: 

2052 fn = self.rbf[coeff] 

2053 except AttributeError: 

2054 # No radial basis functions at all 

2055 raise AttributeError("No radial basis functions found") 

2056 except KeyError: 

2057 # No RBF for this coefficient 

2058 raise KeyError("No radial basis function for coeff '%s'" % coeff) 

2059 # Number of indices given 

2060 nd = len(I) 

2061 # Loop through indices 

2062 for n, i in enumerate(I): 

2063 # Try to extract 

2064 try: 

2065 # Get the *ith* list entry 

2066 fn = fn[i] 

2067 except TypeError: 

2068 # Reached RBF too soon 

2069 raise TypeError( 

2070 ("RBF for '%s':\n" % coeff) + 

2071 ("Expecting %i-dimensional " % nd) + 

2072 ("array but found %i-dim" % n)) 

2073 # Test type 

2074 if fn.__class__.__name__ not in ["function", "Rbf"]: 

2075 raise TypeError("RBF '%s' index %i is not callable" % (coeff, I)) 

2076 # Output 

2077 return fn 

2078 

2079 # RBF lookup 

2080 def eval_rbf(self, coeff, args, x, **kw): 

2081 """Evaluate a single radial basis function 

2082 

2083 :Call: 

2084 >>> y = DBc.eval_rbf(coeff, args, x) 

2085 :Inputs: 

2086 *DBc*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

2087 Coefficient database interface 

2088 *coeff*: :class:`str` 

2089 Name of coefficient to evaluate 

2090 *args*: :class:`list` | :class:`tuple` 

2091 List of lookup key names 

2092 *x*: :class:`list` | :class:`tuple` | :class:`np.ndarray` 

2093 Vector of values for each argument in *args* 

2094 :Outputs: 

2095 *y*: ``None`` | :class:`float` | ``DBc[coeff].__class__`` 

2096 Interpolated value from ``DBc[coeff]`` 

2097 :Versions: 

2098 * 2018-12-31 ``@ddalle``: First version 

2099 """ 

2100 # Get the radial basis function 

2101 f = self.get_rbf(coeff) 

2102 # Evaluate 

2103 return f(*x) 

2104 

2105 # --- Generic Function --- 

2106 # Generic function 

2107 def eval_function(self, coeff, args, x, **kw): 

2108 """Evaluate a single user-saved function 

2109 

2110 :Call: 

2111 >>> y = DBc.eval_function(coeff, args, x) 

2112 :Inputs: 

2113 *DBc*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

2114 Coefficient database interface 

2115 *coeff*: :class:`str` 

2116 Name of coefficient to evaluate 

2117 *args*: :class:`list` | :class:`tuple` 

2118 List of lookup key names 

2119 *x*: :class:`list` | :class:`tuple` | :class:`np.ndarray` 

2120 Vector of values for each argument in *args* 

2121 :Outputs: 

2122 *y*: ``None`` | :class:`float` | ``DBc[coeff].__class__`` 

2123 Interpolated value from ``DBc[coeff]`` 

2124 :Versions: 

2125 * 2018-12-31 ``@ddalle``: First version 

2126 """ 

2127 # Get the function 

2128 try: 

2129 f = self.eval_func[coeff] 

2130 except AttributeError: 

2131 # No evaluation functions set 

2132 raise AttributeError( 

2133 "No evaluation functions present in database") 

2134 except KeyError: 

2135 # No keys 

2136 raise KeyError( 

2137 "No evaluation function for coeff '%s'" % coeff) 

2138 # Evaluate 

2139 if self.eval_func_self.get(coeff): 

2140 # Use reference to *self* 

2141 return f(self, *x, **kw) 

2142 else: 

2143 # Stand-alone function 

2144 return f(*x, **kw) 

2145 

2146 # --- RBF-linear --- 

2147 # Multiple RBF lookup 

2148 def eval_rbf_linear(self, coeff, args, x, **kw): 

2149 """Evaluate two RBFs at slices of first *arg* and interpolate 

2150 

2151 :Call: 

2152 >>> y = DBc.eval_rbf_linear(coeff, args, x) 

2153 :Inputs: 

2154 *DBc*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

2155 Coefficient database interface 

2156 *coeff*: :class:`str` 

2157 Name of coefficient to evaluate 

2158 *args*: :class:`list` | :class:`tuple` 

2159 List of lookup key names 

2160 *x*: :class:`list` | :class:`tuple` | :class:`np.ndarray` 

2161 Vector of values for each argument in *args* 

2162 :Outputs: 

2163 *y*: ``None`` | :class:`float` | ``DBc[coeff].__class__`` 

2164 Interpolated value from ``DBc[coeff]`` 

2165 :Versions: 

2166 * 2018-12-31 ``@ddalle``: First version 

2167 """ 

2168 # Lookup value for first variable 

2169 i0, i1, f = self.get_bkpt_index(args[0], x[0]) 

2170 # Get lookup functions for *i0* and *i1* 

2171 f0 = self.get_rbf(coeff, i0) 

2172 f1 = self.get_rbf(coeff, i1) 

2173 # Evaluate both functions 

2174 y0 = f0(*x[1:]) 

2175 y1 = f1(*x[1:]) 

2176 # Interpolate 

2177 y = (1-f)*y0 + f*y1 

2178 # Output 

2179 return y 

2180 

2181 # --- RBF-schedule --- 

2182 # Multiple RBF lookup, curvilinear 

2183 def eval_rbf_schedule(self, coeff, args, x, **kw): 

2184 """Evaluate a single radial basis function 

2185 

2186 :Call: 

2187 >>> y = DBc.eval_rbf_schedule(coeff, args, x) 

2188 :Inputs: 

2189 *DBc*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

2190 Coefficient database interface 

2191 *coeff*: :class:`str` 

2192 Name of coefficient to evaluate 

2193 *args*: :class:`list` | :class:`tuple` 

2194 List of lookup key names 

2195 *x*: :class:`list` | :class:`tuple` | :class:`np.ndarray` 

2196 Vector of values for each argument in *args* 

2197 :Outputs: 

2198 *y*: ``None`` | :class:`float` | ``DBc[coeff].__class__`` 

2199 Interpolated value from ``DBc[coeff]`` 

2200 :Versions: 

2201 * 2018-12-31 ``@ddalle``: First version 

2202 """ 

2203 # Extrapolation option 

2204 extrap = kw.get("extrap", False) 

2205 # Get lookup points at both sides of scheduling key 

2206 i0, i1, f, x0, x1 = self.get_schedule(list(args), x, extrap=extrap) 

2207 # Get lookup functions for *i0* and *i1* 

2208 f0 = self.get_rbf(coeff, i0) 

2209 f1 = self.get_rbf(coeff, i1) 

2210 # Evaluate the RBFs at both slices 

2211 y0 = f0(*x0) 

2212 y1 = f1(*x1) 

2213 # Interpolate between the slices 

2214 y = (1-f)*y0 + f*y1 

2215 # Output 

2216 return y 

2217 

2218 # --- Nearest --- 

2219 # Exact match 

2220 def eval_exact(self, coeff, args, x, **kw): 

2221 """Evaluate a coefficient by looking up exact matches 

2222 

2223 :Call: 

2224 >>> y = DBc.eval_exact(coeff, args, x, **kw) 

2225 >>> Y = DBc.eval_exact(coeff, args, x, **kw) 

2226 :Inputs: 

2227 *DBc*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

2228 Coefficient database interface 

2229 *coeff*: :class:`str` 

2230 Name of coefficient to evaluate 

2231 *args*: :class:`list` | :class:`tuple` 

2232 List of lookup key names 

2233 *x*: :class:`list` | :class:`tuple` | :class:`np.ndarray` 

2234 Vector of values for each argument in *args* 

2235 *tol*: {``1.0e-4``} | :class:`float` > 0 

2236 Default tolerance for exact match 

2237 *tols*: {``{}``} | :class:`dict` (:class:`float` > 0) 

2238 Dictionary of key-specific tolerances 

2239 :Outputs: 

2240 *y*: ``None`` | :class:`float` | ``DBc[coeff].__class__`` 

2241 Value of ``DBc[coeff]`` exactly matching *x* 

2242 *Y*: :class:`np.ndarray` 

2243 Multiple values matching exactly 

2244 :Versions: 

2245 * 2018-12-30 ``@ddalle``: First version 

2246 """ 

2247 # Possible values 

2248 try: 

2249 # Extract coefficient 

2250 V = self[coeff] 

2251 except KeyError: 

2252 # Missing key 

2253 raise KeyError("Coefficient '%s' is not present" % coeff) 

2254 # Create mask 

2255 I = np.arange(len(V)) 

2256 # Tolerance dictionary 

2257 tols = kw.get("tols", {}) 

2258 # Default tolerance 

2259 tol = 1.0e-4 

2260 # Loop through keys 

2261 for i, k in enumerate(args): 

2262 # Get value 

2263 xi = x[i] 

2264 # Get tolerance 

2265 toli = tols.get(k, kw.get("tol", tol)) 

2266 # Apply test 

2267 qi = np.abs(self[k][I] - xi) <= toli 

2268 # Combine constraints 

2269 I = I[qi] 

2270 # Break if no matches 

2271 if len(I) == 0: 

2272 return None 

2273 # Test number of outputs 

2274 if len(I) == 1: 

2275 # Single output 

2276 return V[I[0]] 

2277 else: 

2278 # Multiple outputs 

2279 return V[I] 

2280 

2281 # Lookup nearest value 

2282 def eval_nearest(self, coeff, args, x, **kw): 

2283 """Evaluate a coefficient by looking up nearest match 

2284 

2285 :Call: 

2286 >>> y = DBc.eval_nearest(coeff, args, x, **kw) 

2287 :Inputs: 

2288 *DBc*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

2289 Coefficient database interface 

2290 *coeff*: :class:`str` 

2291 Name of coefficient to evaluate 

2292 *args*: :class:`list` | :class:`tuple` 

2293 List of lookup key names 

2294 *x*: :class:`list` | :class:`tuple` | :class:`np.ndarray` 

2295 Vector of values for each argument in *args* 

2296 *weights*: {``{}``} | :class:`dict` (:class:`float` > 0) 

2297 Dictionary of key-specific distance weights 

2298 :Outputs: 

2299 *y*: ``None`` | :class:`float` | ``DBc[coeff].__class__`` 

2300 Value of ``DBc[coeff]`` exactly matching *x* 

2301 :Versions: 

2302 * 2018-12-30 ``@ddalle``: First version 

2303 """ 

2304 # Possible values 

2305 try: 

2306 # Extract coefficient 

2307 V = self[coeff] 

2308 except KeyError: 

2309 # Missing key 

2310 raise KeyError("Coefficient '%s' is not present" % coeff) 

2311 # Array length 

2312 n = len(V) 

2313 # Initialize distances 

2314 d = np.zeros(V.shape, dtype="float") 

2315 # Dictionary of distance weights 

2316 W = kw.get("weights", {}) 

2317 # Loop through keys 

2318 for i, k in enumerate(args): 

2319 # Get value 

2320 xi = x[i] 

2321 # Get weight 

2322 wi = W.get(k, 1.0) 

2323 # Distance 

2324 d += wi*(self[k] - xi)**2 

2325 # Find minimum distance 

2326 j = np.argmin(d) 

2327 # Use that value 

2328 return V[j] 

2329 

2330 # --- RBF construction --- 

2331 # Regularization 

2332 def CreateGlobalRBFs(self, coeffs, args, I=None, **kw): 

2333 """Create global radial basis functions for one or more coeffs 

2334 

2335 :Call: 

2336 >>> DBc.CreateGlobalRBFs(coeffs, args, I=None) 

2337 :Inputs: 

2338 *DBc*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

2339 Coefficient database interface 

2340 *coeffs*: :class:`list` (:class:`str`) 

2341 List of coefficients to interpolate 

2342 *args*: :class:`list` (:class:`str`) 

2343 List of (ordered) input keys, default is from *DBc.bkpts* 

2344 *I*: {``None``} | :class:`np.ndarray` 

2345 Indices of cases to include in RBF (default is all) 

2346 *function*: {``"cubic"``} | :class:`str` 

2347 Radial basis function type 

2348 *smooth*: {``0.0``} | :class:`float` >= 0 

2349 Smoothing factor, ``0.0`` for exact interpolation 

2350 :Outputs: 

2351 *DBi*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

2352 Coefficient database interface with regularized data 

2353 :Versions: 

2354 * 2019-01-01 ``@ddalle``: First version 

2355 """ 

2356 # Create *rbf* attribute if needed 

2357 try: 

2358 # Test if present 

2359 self.rbf 

2360 except AttributeError: 

2361 # Create the attribute 

2362 self.rbf = {} 

2363 # RBF options 

2364 func = kw.get("function", "cubic") 

2365 smooth = kw.get("smooth", 0.0) 

2366 # Default indices 

2367 if I is None: 

2368 # Size of database 

2369 n = len(self[args[0]]) 

2370 # All the indices 

2371 I = np.arange(n) 

2372 # Create tuple of input points 

2373 V = tuple(self[k][I] for k in args) 

2374 # Loop through coefficients 

2375 for coeff in coeffs: 

2376 # Eval arguments for status update 

2377 txt = str(tuple(args)).replace(" ", "") 

2378 # Trim if too long 

2379 if len(txt) > 50: 

2380 txt = txt[:45] + "...)" 

2381 # Status update line 

2382 txt = "Creating RBF for %s%s" % (coeff, txt) 

2383 sys.stdout.write("%-72s\r" % txt) 

2384 sys.stdout.flush() 

2385 # Append reference values to input tuple 

2386 Z = V + (self[coeff][I],) 

2387 # Create a single RBF 

2388 f = scipy.interpolate.rbf.Rbf(*Z, 

2389 function=func, smooth=smooth) 

2390 # Save it 

2391 self.rbf[coeff] = f 

2392 # Clean up the prompt 

2393 sys.stdout.write("%72s\r" % "") 

2394 sys.stdout.flush() 

2395 

2396 # Regularization 

2397 def CreateSliceRBFs(self, coeffs, args, I=None, **kw): 

2398 """Create global radial basis functions for each slice of first *arg* 

2399 

2400 The first entry in *args* is interpreted as a "slice" key; RBFs will be 

2401 constructed at constant values 

2402 :Call: 

2403 >>> DBc.CreateSliceRBFs(coeffs, args, I=None) 

2404 :Inputs: 

2405 *DBc*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

2406 Coefficient database interface 

2407 *coeffs*: :class:`list` (:class:`str`) 

2408 List of coefficients to interpolate 

2409 *args*: :class:`list` (:class:`str`) 

2410 List of (ordered) input keys, default is from *DBc.bkpts* 

2411 *I*: {``None``} | :class:`np.ndarray` 

2412 Indices of cases to include in RBF (default is all) 

2413 *function*: {``"cubic"``} | :class:`str` 

2414 Radial basis function type 

2415 *smooth*: {``0.0``} | :class:`float` >= 0 

2416 Smoothing factor, ``0.0`` for exact interpolation 

2417 :Outputs: 

2418 *DBi*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

2419 Coefficient database interface with regularized data 

2420 :Versions: 

2421 * 2019-01-01 ``@ddalle``: First version 

2422 """ 

2423 # Create *rbf* attribute if needed 

2424 try: 

2425 # Test if present 

2426 self.rbf 

2427 except AttributeError: 

2428 # Create the attribute 

2429 self.rbf = {} 

2430 # RBF options 

2431 func = kw.get("function", "cubic") 

2432 smooth = kw.get("smooth", 0.0) 

2433 # Name of slice key 

2434 skey = args[0] 

2435 # Tolerances 

2436 tols = kw.get("tols", {}) 

2437 # Tolerance for slice key 

2438 tol = kw.get("tol", tols.get(skey, 1e-6)) 

2439 # Default indices 

2440 if I is None: 

2441 # Size of database 

2442 n = len(self[skey]) 

2443 # All the indices 

2444 I = np.arange(n) 

2445 # Get break points for slice key 

2446 B = self.bkpts[skey] 

2447 # Number of slices 

2448 nslice = len(B) 

2449 # Initialize the RBFs 

2450 for coeff in coeffs: 

2451 self.rbf[coeff] = [] 

2452 # Loop through slices 

2453 for b in B: 

2454 # Get slice constraints 

2455 qj = np.abs(self[skey][I] - b) <= tol 

2456 # Select slice and add to list 

2457 J = I[qj] 

2458 # Create tuple of input points 

2459 V = tuple(self[k][J] for k in args[1:]) 

2460 # Create a string for slice coordinate and remaining args 

2461 arg_string_list = ["%s=%g" % (skey,b)] 

2462 arg_string_list += [str(k) for k in args[1:]] 

2463 # Joint list with commas 

2464 arg_string = "(" + (",".join(arg_string_list)) + ")" 

2465 # Loop through coefficients 

2466 for coeff in coeffs: 

2467 # Status update 

2468 txt = "Creating RBF for %s%s" % (coeff, arg_string) 

2469 sys.stdout.write("%-72s\r" % txt[:72]) 

2470 sys.stdout.flush() 

2471 # Append reference values to input tuple 

2472 Z = V + (self[coeff][J],) 

2473 # Create a single RBF 

2474 f = scipy.interpolate.rbf.Rbf(*Z, 

2475 function=func, smooth=smooth) 

2476 # Save it 

2477 self.rbf[coeff].append(f) 

2478 # Clean up the prompt 

2479 sys.stdout.write("%72s\r" % "") 

2480 sys.stdout.flush() 

2481 # > 

2482 

2483 # ============ 

2484 # Data 

2485 # ============ 

2486 # < 

2487 # --- Manual Addition --- 

2488 # Add a field 

2489 def AddCoeff(self, coeff, V, **kw): 

2490 """Add a coefficient to the database, with checks as requested 

2491 

2492 :Call: 

2493 >>> DBc.AddCoeff(coeff, V, **kw) 

2494 :Inputs: 

2495 *DBc*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

2496 Coefficient database interface 

2497 *coeff*: :class:`str` 

2498 Name of new coefficient 

2499 *V*: :class:`np.ndarray` 

2500 Array of values for this new coefficient 

2501 *k*: {``None``} | :class:`str` 

2502 Name of coefficient whose dimension must match *V* 

2503 :Versions: 

2504 * 2018-07-20 ``@ddalle``: First version 

2505 """ 

2506 # Check for a key 

2507 k = kw.get('k') 

2508 # If given, match dimensions 

2509 if k and (k in self.coeffs): 

2510 # Get dimension of *V* and *self[k]* 

2511 nk = self[k].size 

2512 nV = len(V) 

2513 # Check consistency 

2514 if nk != nV: 

2515 raise ValueError("Input array does not match dimension " + 

2516 ("of specified key '%s'" % k)) 

2517 # Set the data 

2518 self[coeff] = np.asarray(V) 

2519 # Add to coefficient list if needed 

2520 if coeff not in self.coeffs: 

2521 self.coeffs.append(coeff) 

2522 

2523 # --- Independent Key Values --- 

2524 # Get the value of an independent variable if possible 

2525 def GetXValues(self, k, I=None, **kw): 

2526 """Get values of specified coefficients, which may need conversion 

2527 

2528 This function can be used to calculate independent variables that are 

2529 derived from extant data columns. For example if columns *alpha* and 

2530 *beta* (for angle of attack and angle of sideslip, respectively) are 

2531 present and the user wants to get the total angle of attack *aoap*, 

2532 this function will attempt to use ``DBc.eval_arg_converters["aoap"]`` 

2533 to convert available *alpha* and *beta* data. 

2534 

2535 :Call: 

2536 >>> V = DBc.GetXValues(k, I=None, **kw) 

2537 :Inputs: 

2538 *DBc*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

2539 Coefficient database interface 

2540 *I*: ``None`` | :class:`np.ndarray` | :class:`int` 

2541 Subset indices or index 

2542 *kw*: :class:`dict` 

2543 Dictionary of values to use instead of of columns of *DBc* 

2544 *IndexKW*: ``True`` | {``False``} 

2545 Option to use *kw[k][I]* instead of just *kw[k]* 

2546 :Outputs: 

2547 *V*: :class:`np.ndarray` | :class:`float` 

2548 Array of values for variable *k* (scalar if *I* is scalar) 

2549 :Versions: 

2550 * 2019-03-12 ``@ddalle``: First version 

2551 """ 

2552 # Option for processing keywrods 

2553 qkw = kw.pop("IndexKW", False) 

2554 # Check for direct membership 

2555 if k in kw: 

2556 # Get values from inputs 

2557 V = kw[k] 

2558 # Checking for quick output 

2559 if not qkw: return V 

2560 elif k in self: 

2561 # Get all values from column 

2562 V = self[k] 

2563 else: 

2564 # Get converter 

2565 f = self.get_eval_arg_converter(k) 

2566 # Check for converter 

2567 if f is None: 

2568 raise ValueError("No converter for key '%s'" % k) 

2569 # Create a dictionary of values 

2570 X = dict(self, **kw) 

2571 # Attempt to convert 

2572 try: 

2573 # Use entire dictionary as inputs 

2574 V = f(**X) 

2575 except Exception: 

2576 raise ValueError("Conversion function for '%s' failed" % k) 

2577 # Check for indexing 

2578 if I is None: 

2579 # No subset 

2580 return V 

2581 elif typeutils.isarray(V): 

2582 # Apply subset 

2583 return V[I] 

2584 else: 

2585 # Not subsettable 

2586 return V 

2587 

2588 # Get independent variable from eval inputs 

2589 def GetEvalXValues(self, k, *a, **kw): 

2590 """Return values of a coefficient from inputs to :func:`__call__` 

2591 

2592 For example, this can be used to derive the total angle of attack from 

2593 inputs to an evaluation call to *CN* when it is a function of *mach*, 

2594 *alpha*, and *beta*. This function attempts to use 

2595 :func:`DBc.eval_arg_converters`. 

2596 

2597 :Call: 

2598 >>> V = DBc.GetEvalXValues(k, *a, **kw) 

2599 >>> V = DBc.GetEvalXValues(k, coeff, x1, x2, ..., k3=x3) 

2600 :Inputs: 

2601 *DBc*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

2602 Coefficient database interface 

2603 *k*: :class:`str` 

2604 Name of key to calculate 

2605 *coeff*: :class:`str` 

2606 Name of coefficient 

2607 *x1*: :class:`float` | :class:`np.ndarray` 

2608 Value(s) of first argument 

2609 *x2*: :class:`float` | :class:`np.ndarray` 

2610 Value(s) of second argument, if applicable 

2611 *k3*: :class:`str` 

2612 Name of third argument or optional variant 

2613 *x3*: :class:`float` | :class:`np.ndarray` 

2614 Value(s) of argument *k3*, if applicable 

2615 :Outputs: 

2616 *V*: :class:`np.ndarray` 

2617 Values of key *k* from conditions in *a* and *kw* 

2618 :Versions: 

2619 * 2019-03-12 ``@ddalle``: First version 

2620 """ 

2621 # Process coefficient 

2622 X = self.get_arg_value_dict(*a, **kw) 

2623 # Check if key is present 

2624 if k in X: 

2625 # Return values 

2626 return X[k] 

2627 else: 

2628 # Get dictionary of converters 

2629 converters = getattr(self, "eval_arg_converters", {}) 

2630 # Check for membership 

2631 if k not in converters: 

2632 raise ValueError( 

2633 "Could not interpret independent variable '%s'" % k) 

2634 # Get converter 

2635 f = converters[k] 

2636 # Check class 

2637 if not hasattr(f, "__call__"): 

2638 raise TypeError("Converter is not callable") 

2639 # Attempt to convert 

2640 try: 

2641 # Use entire dictionary as inputs 

2642 V = f(**X) 

2643 except Exception: 

2644 raise ValueError("Conversion function for '%s' failed" % k) 

2645 # Output 

2646 return V 

2647 

2648 # --- Dependent Key Values --- 

2649 # Get exact values 

2650 def GetExactYValues(self, coeff, I=None, **kw): 

2651 """Get exact values of a data coefficient 

2652 

2653 :Call: 

2654 >>> V = DBc.GetExactYValues(coeff, I=None, **kw) 

2655 :Inputs: 

2656 *DBc*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

2657 Coefficient database interface 

2658 *coeff*: :class:`str` 

2659 Name of data coefficient to extract 

2660 :Versions: 

2661 * 2019-03-13 ``@ddalle``: First version 

2662 """ 

2663 # Check for direct membership 

2664 if coeff in self: 

2665 # Get all values from column 

2666 V = self[coeff] 

2667 # Check for indexing 

2668 if I is None: 

2669 # No subset 

2670 return V 

2671 else: 

2672 # Apply subset 

2673 return V[I] 

2674 else: 

2675 # Get evaluation type 

2676 meth = self.get_eval_method(coeff) 

2677 # Only allow "function" type 

2678 if meth != "function": 

2679 raise ValueError( 

2680 ("Cannot evaluate exact values for '%s', " % coeff) + 

2681 ("which has method '%s'" % meth)) 

2682 # Get args 

2683 args = self.get_eval_arg_list(coeff) 

2684 # Create inputs 

2685 a = tuple([self.GetXValues(k, I, **kw) for k in args]) 

2686 # Evaluate 

2687 V = self.__call__(coeff, *a) 

2688 # Output 

2689 return V 

2690 

2691 # --- Search --- 

2692 # Find matches 

2693 def FindMatches(self, args, *a, **kw): 

2694 """Find cases that match a condition within a certain tolerance 

2695 

2696 :Call: 

2697 >>> I, J = DBc.FindMatches(args, *a, **kw) 

2698 :Inputs: 

2699 *DBc*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

2700 Coefficient database interface 

2701 *args*: :class:`list` (:class:`str`) 

2702 List of argument names to match 

2703 *a*: :class:`tuple`\ [:class:`float`] 

2704 Values of the arguments 

2705 *tol*: {``1e-4``} | :class:`float` >= 0 

2706 Default tolerance for all *args* 

2707 *tols*: {``{}``} | :class:`dict` (:class:`float` >= 0) 

2708 Dictionary of tolerances specific to arguments 

2709 *kw*: :class:`dict` 

2710 Additional values to use during evaluation 

2711 :Outputs: 

2712 *I*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`int`] 

2713 Indices of cases in *DBc* that match a point in (*a*, *kw*) 

2714 *J*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`int`] 

2715 Indices of entries in (*a*, *kw*) that have a match in *DBc* 

2716 :Versions: 

2717 * 2019-03-11 ``@ddalle``: First version 

2718 """ 

2719 # --- Input Checks --- 

2720 # Find a valid argument 

2721 a0 = None 

2722 for arg in args: 

2723 # Check if it's present 

2724 if arg in self: 

2725 # Found at least one valid argument 

2726 a0 = arg 

2727 break 

2728 # Check for error 

2729 if a0 is None: 

2730 raise ValueError( 

2731 "Cannot find matches for argument list %s" % args) 

2732 # Overall tolerance default 

2733 tol = kw.pop("tol", 1e-4) 

2734 # Specific tolerances 

2735 tols = kw.pop("tols", {}) 

2736 # Number of values 

2737 n = len(self[arg]) 

2738 # --- Argument values --- 

2739 # Initialize lookup point 

2740 x = [] 

2741 # Loop through arguments 

2742 for i, k in enumerate(args): 

2743 # Get value 

2744 xi = self.get_arg_value(i, k, *a, **kw) 

2745 # Save it 

2746 x.append(np.asarray(xi)) 

2747 # Normalize arguments 

2748 X, dims = self.__class__.NormalizeArguments(x, True) 

2749 # Number of test points 

2750 nx = np.prod(dims) 

2751 # --- Checks --- 

2752 # Initialize tests for database indices (set to ``False``) 

2753 MI = np.arange(n) < 0 

2754 # Initialize tests for input data indices (set to ``False``) 

2755 MJ = np.arange(nx) < 0 

2756 # Loop through entries 

2757 for i in range(nx): 

2758 # Initialize tests for this point (set to ``True``) 

2759 Mi = np.arange(n) > -1 

2760 # Loop through arguments 

2761 for j, k in enumerate(args): 

2762 # Get total set of values 

2763 Xk = self.get_all_values(k) 

2764 # Check if present 

2765 if (k is None) or (Xk is None): 

2766 continue 

2767 # Check size 

2768 if (i == 0) and (len(Xk) != n): 

2769 raise ValueError( 

2770 ("Parameter '%s' has size %i, " % (k, len(Xk))) + 

2771 ("expecting %i" % n)) 

2772 # Get argument value 

2773 xi = X[j][i] 

2774 # Get tolerance for this key 

2775 xtol = tols.get(k, tol) 

2776 # Check tolerance 

2777 Mi = np.logical_and(Mi, np.abs(Xk-xi) <= xtol) 

2778 # Combine point constraints 

2779 MI = np.logical_or(MI, Mi) 

2780 # Check for any matches of this data point 

2781 MJ[i] = np.any(Mi) 

2782 # Convert masks to indices 

2783 I = np.where(MI)[0] 

2784 J = np.where(MJ)[0] 

2785 # Return combined set of matches 

2786 return I, J 

2787 

2788 # Find matches 

2789 def FindMatchesPair(self, DB2, args, args_test, *a, **kw): 

2790 """Find cases that match conditions in two databases within tolerances 

2791 

2792 :Call: 

2793 >>> I1, I2, J = DBc.FindMatchesPair(DB2, args, args_test, *a, **kw) 

2794 :Inputs: 

2795 *DBc*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

2796 Coefficient database interface 

2797 *DB2*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

2798 Second coefficient database interface 

2799 *args*: :class:`list` (:class:`str`) 

2800 List of argument names to match 

2801 *args_test*: :class:`list` (:class:`str`) 

2802 Additional arguments required for *DBc* and *DB2* match 

2803 *a*: :class:`tuple`\ [:class:`float`] 

2804 Values of the arguments 

2805 *tol*: {``1e-4``} | :class:`float` >= 0 

2806 Default tolerance for all *args* 

2807 *tols*: {``{}``} | :class:`dict` (:class:`float` >= 0) 

2808 Dictionary of tolerances specific to arguments 

2809 *unique*: ``True`` | {``False``} 

2810 Option to only allow indices to appear once in *I1* and *I2* 

2811 *kw*: :class:`dict` 

2812 Additional values to use during evaluation 

2813 :Outputs: 

2814 *I1*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`int`] 

2815 Indices of cases in *DBc* that match a point in (*a*, *kw*) 

2816 *I2*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`int`] 

2817 Indices of cases in *DB2* that match a point in (*a*, *kw*) 

2818 *J*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`int`] 

2819 Indices of entries in (*a*, *kw*) that have a match in *DBc* 

2820 :Versions: 

2821 * 2019-03-11 ``@ddalle``: First version 

2822 """ 

2823 # --- Input Checks --- 

2824 # Find a valid argument 

2825 a0 = None 

2826 for arg in args: 

2827 # Check if it's present 

2828 if arg in self: 

2829 # Found at least one valid argument 

2830 a0 = arg 

2831 break 

2832 # Check for error 

2833 if a0 is None: 

2834 raise ValueError( 

2835 "Cannot find matches for argument list %s" % args) 

2836 # Overall tolerance default 

2837 tol = kw.pop("tol", 1e-4) 

2838 # Specific tolerances 

2839 tols = kw.pop("tols", {}) 

2840 # Uniqueness option 

2841 unique = kw.pop("unique", False) 

2842 # Number of values 

2843 n1 = len(self[arg]) 

2844 n2 = len(DB2[arg]) 

2845 # --- Argument values --- 

2846 # Initialize lookup point 

2847 x = [] 

2848 # Loop through arguments 

2849 for i, k in enumerate(args): 

2850 # Get value 

2851 xi = self.get_arg_value(i, k, *a, **kw) 

2852 # Save it 

2853 x.append(np.asarray(xi)) 

2854 # Normalize arguments 

2855 X, dims = self.__class__.NormalizeArguments(x, True) 

2856 # Number of test points 

2857 nx = np.prod(dims) 

2858 # --- Checks --- 

2859 # Initialize tests for database indices (set to ``False``) 

2860 I1 = [] 

2861 I2 = [] 

2862 # Initialize tests for input data indices (set to ``False``) 

2863 M = np.arange(nx) < 0 

2864 # Loop through entries 

2865 for i in range(nx): 

2866 # Initialize tests for this point (set to ``True``) 

2867 M1 = np.arange(n1) > -1 

2868 M2 = np.arange(n2) > -1 

2869 # Loop through arguments 

2870 for j, k in enumerate(args): 

2871 # Get total set of values 

2872 Xk1 = self.get_all_values(k) 

2873 Xk2 = DB2.get_all_values(k) 

2874 # Check if present 

2875 if k is None: 

2876 # Null key, not sure why this would happen 

2877 continue 

2878 elif (Xk1 is None) or (Xk2 is None): 

2879 # Failed to find in one or both databases 

2880 continue 

2881 # Check size 

2882 if (i == 0) and (len(Xk1) != n1): 

2883 raise ValueError( 

2884 ("Parameter '%s' has size %i, " % (k, len(Xk1))) + 

2885 ("expecting %i" % n1)) 

2886 elif (i == 0) and (len(Xk2) != n2): 

2887 raise ValueError( 

2888 ("Parameter '%s' has size %i, " % (k, len(Xk2))) + 

2889 ("expecting %i" % n2)) 

2890 # Get argument value 

2891 xi = X[j][i] 

2892 # Get tolerance for this key 

2893 xtol = tols.get(k, tol) 

2894 # Check tolerance 

2895 M1 = np.logical_and(M1, np.abs(Xk1-xi) <= xtol) 

2896 M2 = np.logical_and(M2, np.abs(Xk2-xi) <= xtol) 

2897 # Convert to indices 

2898 J1 = np.where(M1)[0] 

2899 J2 = np.where(M2)[0] 

2900 # Check empty 

2901 if (J1.size == 0) or (J2.size == 0): 

2902 continue 

2903 # Loop through candidates from *DBc* 

2904 for j1 in J1: 

2905 # Initialize matches to *DB2* 

2906 M3 = np.arange(J2.size) > -1 

2907 # Loop through constraint arguments 

2908 for k in args_test: 

2909 # Get value from *DBc* and *DB2* 

2910 xk1 = self.GetXValues(k, j1) 

2911 Xk2 = DB2.GetXValues(k, J2) 

2912 # Get tolerance for this key 

2913 xtol = tols.get(k, tol) 

2914 # Combine constraints 

2915 M3 = np.logical_and(M3, np.abs(Xk2-xk1) <= xtol) 

2916 # Convert to indices 

2917 I3 = np.where(M3)[0] 

2918 # Number of matches 

2919 m3 = I3.size 

2920 # Check for matches 

2921 if m3 == 0: continue 

2922 # Save input data index: at least one pair match found 

2923 M[i] = True 

2924 # Save matches 

2925 for j2 in J2[I3]: 

2926 # Save indices 

2927 I1.append(j1) 

2928 I2.append(j2) 

2929 # Check uniqueness flag 

2930 if unique: 

2931 # Remove *i2* from *M2* 

2932 M2[i2] = False 

2933 # Update *J2* 

2934 J2 = np.where(M2)[0] 

2935 break 

2936 # Convert to arrays 

2937 I1 = np.asarray(I1) 

2938 I2 = np.asarray(I2) 

2939 # Convert masks to indices 

2940 J = np.where(M)[0] 

2941 # Return combined set of matches 

2942 return I1, I2, J 

2943 

2944 # Find matches 

2945 def FindMatchesPairIndex(self, DB2, args_test, I=None, **kw): 

2946 """Find indices of cases that have matches in both databases 

2947 

2948 :Call: 

2949 >>> I1, I2, J = DBc.FindMatches(DB2, args_test, I=None, **kw) 

2950 :Inputs: 

2951 *DBc*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

2952 Coefficient database interface 

2953 *DB2*: :class:`tnakit.db.db1.DBCoeff` 

2954 Second coefficient database interface 

2955 *args_test*: :class:`list` (:class:`str`) 

2956 Additional arguments required for *DBc* and *DB2* match 

2957 *I*: {``None``} | :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`int`] 

2958 Indices of cases in *DBc* to consider 

2959 *tol*: {``1e-4``} | :class:`float` >= 0 

2960 Default tolerance for all *args* 

2961 *tols*: {``{}``} | :class:`dict` (:class:`float` >= 0) 

2962 Dictionary of tolerances specific to arguments 

2963 *unique*: ``True`` | {``False``} 

2964 Option to only allow indices to appear once in *I1* and *I2* 

2965 :Outputs: 

2966 *I1*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`int`] 

2967 Indices of cases in *DBc* from *I* that match a *DB2* case 

2968 *I2*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`int`] 

2969 Indices of *I1* cases in *DB2* 

2970 *J*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`int`] 

2971 Indices of *I1* entries in *I* 

2972 :Versions: 

2973 * 2019-03-21 ``@ddalle``: First version 

2974 """ 

2975 # --- Input Checks --- 

2976 # Check constraint count 

2977 if not typeutils.isarray(args_test): 

2978 # Not a list 

2979 raise TypeError("List of test arguments must be list-like") 

2980 elif len(args_test) == 0: 

2981 # Empty list 

2982 raise ValueError("At least one test argument must be given") 

2983 # Pick test argument for sizing candidate arrays 

2984 arg = args_test[0] 

2985 # Overall tolerance default 

2986 tol = kw.pop("tol", 1e-4) 

2987 # Specific tolerances 

2988 tols = kw.pop("tols", {}) 

2989 # Uniqueness option 

2990 unique = kw.pop("unique", False) 

2991 # Number of values 

2992 n1 = len(self[arg]) 

2993 n2 = len(DB2[arg]) 

2994 # Default candidate list 

2995 if I is None: 

2996 I = np.arange(n1) 

2997 # --- Checks --- 

2998 # Initialize lists of finds 

2999 I1 = [] 

3000 I2 = [] 

3001 # Initialize find indices 

3002 J = [] 

3003 # Loop through entries 

3004 for (j, i) in enumerate(I): 

3005 # Initialize tests for this point (set to ``True``) 

3006 M2 = np.arange(n2) > -1 

3007 # Loop through arguments 

3008 for k in args_test: 

3009 # Don't test if not a data key 

3010 if k not in self: continue 

3011 # Get total set of values 

3012 xk1 = self.GetXValues(k, i) 

3013 Xk2 = DB2.get_all_values(k) 

3014 # Check if present 

3015 if k is None: 

3016 # Null key, not sure why this would happen 

3017 continue 

3018 elif Xk2 is None: 

3019 # Failed to find in one or both databases 

3020 continue 

3021 # Check size 

3022 elif (i == 0) and (len(Xk2) != n2): 

3023 raise ValueError( 

3024 ("Parameter '%s' has size %i, " % (k, len(Xk2))) + 

3025 ("expecting %i" % n2)) 

3026 # Get tolerance for this key 

3027 xtol = tols.get(k, tol) 

3028 # Check tolerance 

3029 M2 = np.logical_and(M2, np.abs(Xk2-xk1) <= xtol) 

3030 # Convert to indices 

3031 J2 = np.where(M2)[0] 

3032 # Check empty 

3033 if (J2.size == 0): 

3034 continue 

3035 # Loop through candidates from *DBc* 

3036 for j2 in J2: 

3037 # Save indices 

3038 I1.append(i) 

3039 I2.append(j2) 

3040 # Save indices of indices 

3041 J.append(j) 

3042 # Check uniqueness flag 

3043 if unique: break 

3044 # Convert to arrays 

3045 I1 = np.asarray(I1) 

3046 I2 = np.asarray(I2) 

3047 J = np.asarray(J) 

3048 # Return combined set of matches 

3049 return I1, I2, J
